articles.headline: Talking Peace in Sudan, the U.A.E. Secretly Fuels the Fight
articles.snippet: From a remote air base in Chad, the Emirates is giving arms and medical treatment to fighters on one side in Sudan’s worsening war, officials say.
articles.abstract: From a remote air base in Chad, the Emirates is giving arms and medical treatment to fighters on one side in Sudan’s worsening war, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under the guise of saving refugees, the United Arab Emirates is running an elaborate covert operation to back one side in Sudan’s spiraling war — supplying powerful weapons and drones, treating injured fighters and airlifting the most serious cases to one of its military hospitals, according to a dozen current and former officials from the United States, Europe and several African countries.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Christoph Koettl and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Sri Lankan Baker’s Baguette Conquers France
articles.snippet: After 17 years in France, Tharshan Selvarajah has yet to apply for citizenship. But he has made bread for President Emmanuel Macron.
articles.abstract: After 17 years in France, Tharshan Selvarajah has yet to apply for citizenship. But he has made bread for President Emmanuel Macron.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most mornings, around 6:30, Tharshan Selvarajah arrives at the Élysée Palace, seat of the French presidency, and unloads around 30 baguettes into the security scanner.

articles.headline: Inflation Measure Favored by the Fed Cooled in August
articles.snippet: The Personal Consumption Expenditures Index climbed more slowly, after cutting out food and fuel prices for a sense of the underlying trend.
articles.abstract: The Personal Consumption Expenditures Index climbed more slowly, after cutting out food and fuel prices for a sense of the underlying trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials received more good news in their battle against rapid inflation on Friday, when a key inflation measure continued to slow, the latest evidence that a return to normal after the pandemic and higher interest rates are combining to wrestle rapid price increases back to a more normal pace.

articles.headline: Wall Street on Edge After Worst Month of the Year
articles.snippet: A series of potential problems, including rising oil prices and labor strikes, have prompted a much warier mood among investors.
articles.abstract: A series of potential problems, including rising oil prices and labor strikes, have prompted a much warier mood among investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market staggered to the end of its worst month of the year so far, dragged down by fears of a looming government shutdown, striking autoworkers, surging oil prices and the prospect of interest rates remaining high for longer than previously thought. Combined, they are darkening the outlook for the economy.

articles.headline: Dianne Feinstein, 90, Dies; Oldest Sitting Senator and Fixture of California Politics
articles.snippet: She achieved remarkable political breakthroughs as a woman, becoming San Francisco’s first female mayor and the first woman elected to the Senate from California.
articles.abstract: She achieved remarkable political breakthroughs as a woman, becoming San Francisco’s first female mayor and the first woman elected to the Senate from California.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read the latest updates about Senator Dianne Feinstein’s death and her possible replacement here.

articles.headline: Right Wing Tanks Stopgap Bill in House, Pushing Government Toward a Shutdown
articles.snippet: More than 20 hard-right Republicans defied Speaker Kevin McCarthy and defeated their own party’s bill, making a lapse in funding at midnight on Saturday all but certain.
articles.abstract: More than 20 hard-right Republicans defied Speaker Kevin McCarthy and defeated their own party’s bill, making a lapse in funding at midnight on Saturday all but certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hard-line conservatives on Friday blocked Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s long-shot bid to pass legislation to avert a government shutdown, in an extraordinary display of defiance that made it clear that Congress would almost certainly miss a midnight deadline on Saturday to keep federal funding flowing.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson, Kayla Guo and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: U.A.W. Expands Strikes at Ford and G.M.
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers union said 7,000 more of its members would walk off the job two weeks after it began strikes at the Big Three automakers.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers union said 7,000 more of its members would walk off the job two weeks after it began strikes at the Big Three automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union increased the pressure on Ford Motor and General Motors by extending its strike to two more car assembly plants on Friday, saying the companies had not moved far enough to meet its demands for higher pay and benefits.
